turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 581, William W. Burns, Petitioner, versus State of Ohio.
Mrs. Washington.

turn.speaker: helen_g_washington
turn.label: Ms. Helen G. Washington
turn.text: May it please the Court, my argument will be very brief.

As in Griffin against Illinois and Eskridge against Washington State Prison Board recently decided by this Court, this case concerns an indigent convicted defendant who was deprived of the appeal rights given him by state law, solely because he was too poor to pay one of the costs of appeal, here the docket fee demanded in advance for docketing his appeal papers.

As in the Griffin and Eskridge case the only question is whether the Due Process and Equal Protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment prohibited the state from denying appeal rights given to others, to one who does not have the money to pay the cost.
The details giving rise to this question maybe quickly stated.
The petitioner was convicted by a jury of a felony in a trial court in Ohio.
He was sentenced to life imprisonment in the state penitentiary.
Upon an appeal to the Intermediate Court of Appeals, his conviction was affirmed.
Ohio Law gave him further appeal rights in the Supreme Court of Ohio.
Under the law there is an appeal as of right if a constitutional question is involved.

In other cases one whose conviction of a felony has been affirmed by the Court of Appeals, may move the Supreme Court of Ohio for leave to appeal and will have leave granted if good cause for the appeal is shown.
The state statute and the rules of the Supreme Court provide, however, for the payment of the docket fee of $20 before the appeal papers will be docketed.
This petitioner who was in the penitentiary without the assistant of counsel prepared a motion for leave to appeal, a motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and then affidavit of poverty.
He transmitted these papers to the Supreme Court of Ohio together with a copy of the notice of appeal filed in the Court of Appeal.

The Supreme Court, acting through its clerk, immediately returned his papers to him, with the explanation that the docket fee required by statute and the Court's rule had not have been paid and that an appeal in forma pauperis was not an acceptable substitute.
Thus the Supreme Court of Ohio construed the statute and its rules as denying access through the Court to those who were unable to pay the fee, although everyone else could have his appeal docketed.
Under the Griffin and Eskridge decision such a discriminatory interpretation of the statute cannot stand.

Since Ohio has a general policy of allowing appeals, or appeal rights in the Supreme Court, it under those decisions cannot consistently with the Fourteenth Amendment deny them to one who does not have the money to pay the cost.
I don't think I need to elaborate anymore on that point.
We rest our case on the decisions in the Griffin and Eskridge cases.
On brief the state advances only one reason why those cases should not apply here.

The state says that the petitioner has had one appeal here, his conviction was affirmed and that he is not entitled to anything more, that when Ohio does give a second appeal it can establish any conditions for it that it sees fit.
I think that this is a misreading of Griffin.

The teaching of that case certainly is that if a state does grant appeal, it should grant it to rich and poor alike, that would be regardless of the level at which appeal was, regardless of whether it was the first, second or tenth appeal.
And we submit that this case could return to the Supreme Court of Ohio with appropriate instructions to give petitioner his rights.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Vance.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and justices, please the Court.

I think the whole question before this Court here is whether or not the effect of Griffin should be extended because in Griffin under the statues of the State of Illinois, felony cases are appealed only and directly to the Supreme Court of Illinois.
Misdemeanor cases are appealed to the appellate court.
Before our case can be appealed or considered on appeal by the Supreme Court of the State of Illinois, they had to have a transcript.
Griffin had no transcript and he said he had no money to buy one, therefore, his case was heard in lower court one appeal.
In Ohio it is different.
Our primary appellate court is the Court of Appeals, a three-judge court of which we have ten in the state.
In this case Burns was convicted in the trial court.
He had self retained counsel.
He was not a poor man.
He appealed to the Court of Appeals.
He had his transcript.
He got a full appellate review before the Court of Appeals and his case was affirmed.
Now at that stage, he filed a notice of appeal to the Supreme Court of Ohio.
He did the necessary administrative step two of notifying the prosecuting attorney before he filed his application for an appeal.
At that time as I say he apparently was not indigent, he had his own self retained counsel.
He went out and he had his review.
He dropped and abandoned, at that time that contemplated appeal to the Supreme Court of Ohio.

It was not until years later after Griffin, the Griffin decision had been announced and after he had spent those intervening years in the penitentiary where whatever resources that he might have had when he first went in were undoubtedly dissipated and he was in truth and in fact a pauper, that he then goes and without taking that necessary step of notifying the prosecuting the attorney, he files his notice of appeal in the Court of Appeals and one in the Supreme Court of Ohio and tries to do it on a pauperis affidavit and they send back and say it takes $20 to get here in this Court on that kind of a motion.

turn.text: That's what we are contending, there is no judgment of the Supreme Court of Ohio for this Court to review.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It says on writ of certiorari that the Supreme Court of Ohio --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That implies the Supreme Court of Ohio did something, either affirmatively or negatively which is the record of the Court, there is no record of the Court.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: You have nothing here but a letter from a clerk.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible) from the clerk?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: How can he get one unless the clerk (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yeah that's quite true.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now may I ask you this question --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well he can go to the Supreme Court and ask mandamus or something?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible) but let me ask you this, in his motion for leave to appeal, you say that if you raise a constitutional question in this appeal, he had a right to appeal as a matter of right --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: If the face of the record shows that there is a constitutional record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: His motion has not been denied, has there?

I mean the facts (Inaudible) have not been denied and he alleges that in his motion for leave to appeal, the judgment against him was rendered upon error, prejudicial conflicting with his constitutional guarantees with the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States, he alleges that.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yes, he alleges it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the ground on which he sought the appeal.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And if there is a genuine constitutional question as well, he can appeal as a matter of right and not merely by leave?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there -- have you (Inaudible) -- has your Supreme Court (Inaudible) jurisdiction of mandamus?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yes, the Supreme Court has.
As a matter of fact all of our courts --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We haven't yet got a letter from the clerk saying I would accept your petition for mandamus, have we?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: No, no, and there has been no effort to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not constant, I mean (Inaudible), not so long ago was a case that this Court, but not this Court, but a case where the question was what the power of the Supreme Court (Inaudible) was and it was argued them that statute is clear and every thing else and Chief Judge McGruder wrote for that court that I believe that when I told so, but not before.
How do we know what the Supreme Court of California may do (Inaudible), does anybody know?
Are you prepared to tell us?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: I am not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is Washington prepared to tell us?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you prepared to tell us whether this prisoner can go up and see the Supreme Court personally?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: If he has a case pending, I handle habeas corpus cases and I have had many prisoners who come over and go before a Supreme Court and act as their own counsel, they are always brought over and make a personal appearance.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But this man leaves the jail and goes to see the Supreme Court --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: They have a guard with them, but they do an admirable job of arguing their own case sometimes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Inaudible) he was able to file the document with the Supreme Court of the United States.
I know (Inaudible) and other courts are, but perhaps you can do the same even in Ohio.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well Mr. Vance --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No he didn't, he just (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Wyoming (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Vance I understood you to say that its been your contention all along that this was not -- he was not appealing from the judge on the Court, but this was only a letter from the clerk, do you raise that in your brief?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: We do not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did you raise at any place along the line?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We instead have a judgment.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It's a little late now.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yes it is, I didn't raise it.
The Court raised it and asked me that I (Inaudible) thought about it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You can't foreclose people saying there is no judgment because you didn't raise it.
Is there a judgment?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: No there is only a letter from clerk.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Fine.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: We feel here that the due process, equal protection is not involved, the same rule applies in this man as to all other people who file in the Supreme Court of Ohio.

He had his appeal, he had his transcript, and the Griffin decision is rather a black and white affair, it says the rich here and the poor here, actually we as all know life is great mass of grays, with all degrees of fluence in it.

That here is a man who has $100 saved up, a hard working man who has $100 to pay the matriculation fee of his son, who wants to go to college and he gets into some trouble and he wants to appeal his case and he has to reach down and take this $100 to get in.

But here is the other fellow on the other hand who stole a $1,000 and blew it up in one wild night of entertainment, so he is broke and he gets into that fix and the taxpayers have to let him in for free and furnish him with a lawyer and give him a transcript and let him file a (Inaudible), where the man with a, just a modicum of money has to expend that until he too is a pauper.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well Mr. Vance let me ask you this please, suppose this was a constitutional case and nothing else in it, and the defendant had no money, made his affidavit such as he did here, could he file it, could he document it?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: He could not ender the existing rules of the Court, with this exception and we -- I was afraid that question might be asked.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why is that (Inaudible)[Laughter]

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: And I thought over the lunch period what I would say to you and I do believe that this is it, that the rule making power is the Court itself and if they can make rules they can modify rules and I think in a hard situation where they were caught on the horns of a dilemma, the Court has the plenary power to say that although this is not customary with this Court, in this case we want to hear in this case and you can come in without paying this $20.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright now could they do that just as well if it wasn't a constitutional case, but --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: I think they could, I think it's within the plenary powers of the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To get back to Justice Black's question, how could a man avail himself of that, how could he get into court to have that determined by the Supreme Court if their clerk wouldn't file because he didn't have $20, that's --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: And the answer is that he couldn't, unless the Court through the communications between the clerk and the Court became aware that there was a crucial matter that they wanted to hear.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This court --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Not to my knowledge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Wallace gets many number of letters addressed to the court --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So then treat it as though they were form of certiorari.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Clerks are not (Inaudible) court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well Mr. Vance you have answered Justice Harlan that as far as you knew no one had ever tried to do that, what was the clerk referring to when he said on numerous occasions the court has held that they cannot do that?

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now there must have been somebody --

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: Yes it's a series of letters, but what I thought the justice meant was has anyone got himself into a position where the Court has overridden its own rule.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh I see.

turn.speaker: william_m_vance
turn.label: Mr. William M. Vance
turn.text: As I suggest it might have; Mr. Schoettmer of the prosecuting attorney's office.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: May I please the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Schoettmer.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Counsel suggested that I knew this case personally as of the trial level and however that's just not so, I did not try the case, it's an assistant tried it who is long gone, however it fell upon my shoulders to take it after he left, I have to bury his dead, even though this man is obviously still alive.

Justice Frankfurter I would like to say that your position here, that this is a letter from a clerk and not a judgment is the correct position that this man should go back and do something else and get a judgment first and when I first came into Burns' case in this appeal I had a very similar thought, however, I think we have to concede this fact that this letter from the clerk is in reality and in effect the judgment of the Court.
In other words it would be impossible in Ohio for a citizen to file a mandamus action in the Supreme Court without paying $20.

It is also impossible and there is a court decision on this in the Wanamaker case, Wanamaker versus Miller that counsel for the petitioner has cited, that a petitioner or a plaintiff could not file a mandamus action against the clerk of the Supreme Court in a Court of Appeals.
Even though be could file it in forma pauperis in the Court of Appeals it would not lie against the clerk of the Supreme Court.
The Wannamaker case spells out fairly firmly.
So, admittedly this is --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: What is the citation for the Wannamaker?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: It seems to be in the briefs.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: 160, it's on page ten of petitioner's brief in the note, 164 Ohio State 174.
Here is the case in question, and I think we have to face up to it.

As Your Honor pointed out this is a unique case, we have no record to go back to, we have no law as such except the Griffin, there is no long line of thought on this issue, but I think we can say this, that in the first instance we should concede therefore that the letter of the clerk of the Supreme Court is in effect the judgment of the Ohio Supreme Court, and I say that because in my interpretation of Wannamaker case, there were certain -- there was this mandamus action brought against the clerk of the Supreme Court and the Supreme Court members all stepped down and Court of Appeals members stepped up and made the decision in the Wannamaker case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask the fact, the fact you are telling us that Ohio concedes for the purpose of this case, this Court may treat the letter as the judgment of the Supreme Court of Ohio.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: I think in effect in the law of the Supreme Court of Ohio that that has to be accepted Your Honor, even though we would love --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is not binding -- I want to ask -- that is binding on us.
We have held again and again what the state court thinks of a judgment is not in our view necessarily of a judgment.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well, it is a unique position for that reason.

Our second point that I think we should concede here in this Burns case is it without the payment of $20 by Burns that no papers could be filed in the Supreme Court and therefore he could not file under the law his motion for leave to appeal.
Now Your Honor you mentioned before, so how he could possibly get into court?
Suppose the Supreme Court wanted to hear a case that was in the Court of Appeals, and how could it get to the court?
Has there ever been a circumstance where the Supreme Court has ordered a case that had been heard in the Court of Appeals into its court?
That if Ohio does have that procedure, the Supreme Court can order a decision of the Court of Appeals certified to it.
At this stage of our history in Ohio we have not had the position in such a circumstance that the party could not pay the $20.

Without question in my opinion, if that did happen, if that were true in Burns, without question if the Supreme Court said we want to hear that case from a first district appellate court bring it up here, if Burns comes in and says well Your Honor I don't have $20, I am confident that the Supreme Court of Ohio would say we'll waive the $20 without any question in my mind that the Supreme Court would not (Inaudible) its own order because of its rule of $20.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That wasn't exactly the question I ask.

I assumed of course that the Court could waive its own rule if it wanted to do it, but my question was, were there any cases where the defendant was the one who wanted to have a hearing in the Supreme Court and where the Supreme Court gave him that relief even though he could not pay the $20.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Not that I know of.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes well that's my only question.
I can see the other very, very plainly, but this a little different, you must --

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: On that question, but this just establishes our point that much harder and that is this.

In the light of the concessions that we have made here, these two points, we feel that and we request that it be conceded that a court, the Supreme Court of Ohio, this Court, any court has a right to determine the conditions precedent to the procedure to be followed in perfecting an appeal to that court, as long as they are reasonable.

Now when they are unreasonable, when they are completely out of hand without question, the Court maybe infringing on somebody's rights, but as long as these conditions precedent are reasonable, we feel that without question any court can say what a man has to do in order to perfect an appeal to that court, why?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Even though it denies to an indigent person a right that a person with money could have?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: You Honor I don't know why it's so necessary to say that money is such a separate and distinct type of condition precedent to any other type of condition that might be put forth.
Any number of things a court can say that it has to be done by the defendant or by the appellant in order to get in.
Now why we should select money as some significant or extra important sensitive condition I just don't understand that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What discrimination have you in mind in which you can classify the granting and the not granting, has the element of time within which you must file it?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: That's one Your Honor, no this is another.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Counsel mentioned notice, now let's assume that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What kind of a distinction is there between -- is there discrimination in any sense of that meaning, that one fellow you must give notice as against the fellow who didn't have to give notice, is that it?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: That's right and if one does not, then he doesn't get --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that discrimination in any invidious or hurtful sense?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well, I don't think it's invidious or hurtful and I suggest that to Your Honor in the light of my discussion with the Chief Justice in that, in the history of Ohio we've never had that circumstance develop in an appeal, up to this time, up to this man.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you didn't have that because you didn't have the Griffin case until recently.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The Griffin case didn't make a distinction.
For my point of view it's least fiction to say that was the law all long, it wasn't, it was made so in Griffin.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well, a pauper, what is a pauper as such Your Honor, I know you have -- this Court has declared to what is it, but even here, even in this Court, when you allowed a man to file in a pauper (Inaudible), is he a true pauper?
A true pauper I suggest to this Court without aid without assistance of some kind cannot get into this Court, because you demand of course that he file some written, typewritten pleading.
He must have something here must he not?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: No.
But every convict in Ohio, I suggest has money.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Every what?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Every convict in Ohio has money.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you pay him for work in Ohio?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: We do.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What, how much per day?
How many days would he have to work to earn $20?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: I would say about three months.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Three months?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: He gets about -- a single man in Ohio, this is Revised Code 514516, a single person who is a convict in Ohio gets $0.04 an hour.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean --

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Nine hour day.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Automatically?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Automatically, that's by statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But not -- he doesn't get anything for extra -- you haven't got occupational labors for --

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: No we do not Your Honor, we do not.
But if he has --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But I supposedly if he had money the warden would know it, wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Without question, the warden has to account to it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You make no question, you raise no question as to whether he is a pauper or not in your papers, as I read them, as a fact I thought Mr. Vance conceded it, said he is wholly without funds now.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: The problem -- all right sorry Your Honor, the problem comes out is who has to determine he is a pauper.

He signs an affidavit, and I'm sure the law is fairly general concerning men with these criminal records, should we believe them right off, should the state go out and examine what his accounts are --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible) very different question, that question comes up all the time in the federal court, and even in this Court.
We have applications here asking for relief (Inaudible) and it has (Inaudible) but that isn't the problem in this case is it?

Your problem is what Mr. Justice Harlan suggested, that the instances in which make men really want to appeal to your Supreme Court for another review, haven't got the necessary $20, it's so insignificant, so unreal a limitation upon the power of getting hearing from that Court, that the legislature or the judiciary has the right to make that decision.
That's what this case turns on?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: That's right.
Now the question is if a man has an honest appeal, can he somewhere sometime in his course of conduct after his appeal by the appellant court, get $20?

We maintain that this $20, if you please as set forth by the Court, is one of those reasons, one of those manners, one of those means that the Court uses to stop frivolous appeals, to stop men who were just -- fought the Court to come in and talk to it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I didn't know, I didn't know that you had raised that in your briefs or below.
As I understood, the state does not assert the petitioner's allegation of poverty is in bad faith.
If you've briefed that question in your brief please call my attention to it.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: You Honor it has not been, and for this reason --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And on the contrary haven't you conceded that it's not done that in bad faith.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: In effect on the application for writ of certiorari, we --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well that's why you raise it here.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: We should have raised it at that point and I had in a note here, to have raised it at that time and it was not raised when the application for writ was granted by the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Can you concede at one time and then rely on it later?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: I assume not Your Honor, but I'm only trying to put forth the type of case as this, that this is an important --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We're not interested in the type of case, we're interested in this particular case right here.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: This particular defendant then.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: This is what we're interested in and we think that our decision by this Court, that would go along the line and extend the Griffin case for this defendant is unfortunate, for this reason, already this Court has had the merits, the factual matter of the case before it, in the form of the codefendant who had paid his $20 and who did file application of writ of certiorari to this Court on the merits of the case itself.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What case is that?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: That's was the Lotts case Your Honor.
It was -- I have a note on it.
Lotts versus State of Ohio, certiorari denied December 15, 1958, Supreme Court report, 115 volume 79 number 5 miscellaneous docket 482 are the numbers that I have.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Were they tried together?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, all the way they were jointly tired together.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What was this robbery or what?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: It was burglary of an inhabitant dwelling and which carries of course a life sentence when no mercy is extended by the jury.
Second county indictment was grant larceny in the matter of stealing.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible) that Lotts case where your court --

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: There was Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There was?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If $20 is so small, that to be ignored what about 50 (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well –

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where would you go with that?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Whatever is reasonable Your Honor and each case must stand on its merits as to what is the reasonable.
Now in this case we have $20.
We maintain that $20 is reasonable.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under any circumstances (Inaudible), you maintain --

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- $20 just be ignored?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: In the year 1959 we cannot conceive of a position where a defendant is in such circumstances that if he is -- wants to make a good honest appeal, it is not privilege, it is not flaunting the Court that he somewhere cannot pay his $20 fee.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Through (Inaudible) in the United States.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: I suppose the truth Your Honor.
I think we have to look as to whether it's reasonable or not and Justice Frankfurter made this statement in the Griffin case, he said something to this effect.
In order for -- to avoid or immunize abuse and waste a state may appropriately hedge, not only gives leave for -- about the opportunity to prove a conviction wrong.

When a state not only gives leave for appellate correction of trial errors, but must pay for the cost of its exercise by the indigent, it may protect itself so that frivolous appeals are not subsidized and pubic money is not needlessly spent.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well is that such a small amount that it doesn't -- that it shouldn't preclude any indigent from paying it, why would it be such a burden on the state to waive it?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well, because it fellows like Burns Your Honor, remember this is a deputy sheriff.
I know it's not the record, but we are talking about Burns and who he is and what he has done since he has been in the penitentiary.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That isn't hardly in the case as I see it.
I thought you were talking about people here and not --

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: We are.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and not about a person, I don't find anything in the record on that, but what is the answer to that question?

Now I can see where it's quiet a burden on the state or at least on some state, where you have a trial that involves 2,000 or 3,000 or 4,000 pages of testimony that require them, require the state to pay for that transcript, that's quite an amount of money, but if as you say, any indigent in prison or in America, could if he wanted to pay $20 for access to your Supreme Court, why it would be such a burden on the state to waive that fee when in order to give indigents exactly the same standing before the courts to people with money.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Your Honor as a matter of fact it undoubtedly would not be a burden upon the State of Ohio to waive this $20 filing fee.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then why it is such an important issue here?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well, only because we feel that first of all this man has had his appeal, that the Griffin rule should not be extended, that the Supreme Court of Ohio should have the right to say what are the reasonable necessary procedures and we feel that it is the prerogative of that court to determine its procedural development and we're confident that this Court would say that any reasonable procedure that Supreme Court says it must have is perfectly all right.
We're trying to suggest this Court --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I think no one would disagree with you, if you said that everybody could have but one appeal in the Ohio and that, that stopped right there at the Court of Appeals, but when you prescribe another procedure, above that whereby people who have means can have access to the Supreme Court, but through which indigents can have no access, then it seems to me you've got an entirely different problem.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Well, of course we have to take a position that there -- as to the $20 filing fee and honest appellants, ones who want to be heard, because they have an honest conviction in their rights and in the errors that were committed against them, we feel that there is no such thing as an indigent with less than $20.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So you think it is just a per se case?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: That has to be our position.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I have now read the two Wanamaker cases and it doesn't help me in the slightest with my problem (Inaudible).
The first Wanamaker case says that a lower court can't mandamus the clerk of the Supreme Court, and tell that clerk what did you do with reference to matters before that court, (Inaudible).

And the second Wanamaker case simply would be the general rule that involved this problem at all, that the clerk has always the duty of seeing that the formal requirements are satisfying and he can't pass on the merits of a mandamus, any connection with that and we should think that it's properly prepared or accompanied by regular filing fee, that doesn't deal with my problem at all whether action could be added to the Court, so that the court when it held to waive its requirement of fee, will respond, and not the clerk in giving the general rule, he is just (Inaudible) in that regard.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The appellant in those two cases, with all due respect to Mrs. Washington, you shed no light on my problem at all.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: May I ask you on the second one, how did first -- how did Wanamaker there get notice of the Supreme Court has been held for mandamus against the clerk.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: I don't know that Your Honor.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Exhibit B I think shows you did it by (Inaudible).
Did they decline, did the Supreme Court decline the issues of mandamus for clerk?

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: I think the Court said –

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Yes and then the Supreme Court stepped aside and reversed it, I believe that was right, isn't that right judge?
As I recall the case.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: It came up here to us, that he asked us to reverse their refusal, to give him a mandamus.

turn.speaker: harry_c_schoettmer
turn.label: Mr. Harry C. Schoettmer
turn.text: Yes he did, I believe he denied it Your Honor.
The only point in that case, that I said what I did was this, that I believe the Court goes on to say that the clerk must do whatever the Supreme Court says it must do as a robot, as an (Inaudible).
If he accepts the paper incorrectly against the orders of the Court then he should -- the Court will fire him.
If he refuses to accept papers, and the Court will have to handle him in its own course as it sees fit because it is -- he is its robot.
Now because the clerk turns down the applicant, therefore it is apparently the order of the Court that he do so.
That's what I meant Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mrs. Washington.

turn.speaker: helen_g_washington
turn.label: Ms. Helen G. Washington
turn.text: I don't know whether I ought to get into this view of counsel's concession that the letter of the clerk should be treated as the judgment of the Court.

But the Wanamaker case, if they -- that when the clerk carries out the instructions of the Court he is acting for the Court, and in this case the clerk was carrying out the instructions of the Court, the letter say so --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How you know, how do I know?

turn.speaker: helen_g_washington
turn.label: Ms. Helen G. Washington
turn.text: His letter says so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He simply says this is the regular thing, that you require a filing fee, but the specific problem whether a specific appeal, it then raises the general question whereby a court could say, is it a new problem for us hereafter to indigently establish, he weighs this, was not before the Wanamaker Court and is not to be inferred from the clerk's letter, it is just telling a routine order of (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: helen_g_washington
turn.label: Ms. Helen G. Washington
turn.text: Well, the clerk's letter does indicate that the Court has ruled on this question and that he is following that ruling, at least that is my interpretation of it, and I think for practical purposes it has to be treated as the order or the judgment of the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mrs. Washington before you sit down I would like to express the appreciation of the Court to you for assuming this responsibility of defending this indigent prisoner.
We are always comforted by the fact that members of our bar are willing to do that as a public service and we feel very much indebted to you.

And gentlemen may I say that we appreciate the prudent manner in which you have represented the State of Ohio and also for your very extreme frankness that you have displayed in this case and that of course without regard to decision in this case, very well.
